Hopkins School of Nursing Dedicated Sunday
by Bill Riesen
The Johns Hopkins School
of Nursing was formally
dedicated at a ceremony Sunday afternoon in the Turner
Auditorium.
The School of Nursing was
established as an academic division of the University in the
spring of 1983, and awards a
Bachelor of Science degree with
a major in nursing. The 30
undergraduates making up the
first class began courses earlier
this month.
The school emphasizes both
classroom and clinical instruction. Its facilities occupy the
third floor of the newly
renovated Phipps building, and
include a practice ward and
computer lab with up-to-date
health care software.
The Consortium for Nursing
Education, Inc., consisting of
the Johns Hopkins University,
Johns Hopkins, Church, and
Sinai Hospitals, are sponsoring
the new school.
University President Steven
Muller opened the dedication
ceremony by welcoming the 600
guests who attended and by
praising Carol Gray, Dean of
the School of Nursing, and the
consortium members for their
efforts in founding the school.

of its kind in the past ten years
and one of the few to deal

The purpose of these sym

thirty highly qualified scientists,
is to define areas of science advancing quickly, to be there on
the "cutting edge." It gives

establish lines of future
communication.
